page.title: 09SUTTON PARK BIRMINGHAM 2
page.content: SUTTON PARK, COVERING NEARLY 2,500 ACRES, WAS ORIGINALLY A ROYAL HUNTING GROUND USED BY{KING HENRY VIII}, BUT WAS GIVEN BY ROYAL CHARTER, TO SUTTON COLDFIELD IN 1528. TODAY WILDLIFE COSERVATION IS UPPERMOST IN THE PARKS AIMS. BOTH WYNDLEY AND LONGMOOR POOLS ARE KEPT SOLEY AS BIRD SANCTUARIES FOR A VARIETY OF BIRDS INCLUDING CANADA GEESE, SWANS, HERONS AND A VARIETY OF DUCKS. THE OTHER FOUR POOLS ARE USED FOR BOATING, SWIMMING AND FISHING. NEARLY ALL OF THE PARKLAND IS LEFT IN ITS NATURAL STATE PROVIDING ROUGH PASTURE FOR CATTLE FROM NEARBY FARMS AND NATURAL HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE OF WHICH SQUIRRELS, FOXES AND RABBITS ARE NUMEROUS. THE REMAINING LAND IS USED FOR RECREATIONAL PURPOSES TO CATER FOR THE YOUNG. THE PARK IS EASILY ACCESSIBLE FROM ALL PARTS OF THE TOWN THROUGH ITS SEVEN MAIN GATES.
